Definition.Document:
Energy Storage Capital Expense Optimization

Objective

Each substation in a T&D system has multiple transformers feeding distribution circuits. Each of these substations has a set capacity. Utilities must report capacity overages to regulators. Generally, the sum of all substation transformer ratings defines a substation's capacity. In this case, the utility could monitor the sum of MVA load for all transformers to total MVA normal and 24-hour emergency ratings.  

In order to avoid capacity overages, T&D operators install batteries. Batteries are expensive, so T&D operators must decide carefully what locations make the most sense.  Considerations include:

  • Capability of existing transformers to serve present peak loads
  • Capability of existing transformers to pick up full load of station when other transformer fails
  • Asset health
  • Outage impact
  • Forecasted demand
  • Cost and pricing of battery installation

In general, it makes the most sense to install batteries at substations with high risk of capacity overages. We take this monitoring use case one step further by running what-if scenarios, investigating what would have happened in substations in the past if a transformer had failed.

Link to Organizer Topic

Assemble Data

Process Data

  • Load data is stored in PI - step

Equipment data 

  • Capacity ratings are stored in an SQL database - step

Apply analytics

Build what-if load signals 

  • In this example, we will investigate what would have happened if one transformer had failed during the winter in substation 180
  • First, create capsules for winter with Periodic Condition - step
  • Create load signals for an N-1 scenario that one transformer is lost and the remaining transformer takes on all the load using Formula tool and splice function - step

Identify excursion conditions

  • Use Deviation Search to find when the Winter Scenario load exceeds the 24-hr Emergency Rating - step

Cleanse the load signal to refine excursion characteristics

  • Use Low Pass Filter to cleanse the load signal - step
  • Create another Deviation Search for true excursion detection - step

Quantify count, max duration and energy

  • Use Signal from Condition to totalize differential MVA into MWh - step 
  • Use Scorecard to characterize annual Winter what-if excursion characteristics - step

Scale Across Assets

  • Perform the same what-if analysis on Station 191 using asset swap
    • Trend
    • Scorecard

Results

  • Reduces CapEx by prioritizing battery installation based on actual equipment condition and risk of overload
  • Improves system reliability to avoid $10's of millions in unplanned downtime and CapEx and premature replacement
  • Seeq application allows for
    • Aggregation of data from multiple datasources
    • Investigation of "what-if" scenarios
    • Rapid iteration across assets
  • Installing batteries at a substation improved grid reliability and the ability to meet demand anytime.  Specific benefits include:
    • Solar smoothing: smooth short-term changes in voltage due to intermittent generation
    • Distribution deferral: non-wires alternatives to defer or eliminate the need for traditional utility upgrade
    • Outage management: reduces the cost of deploying mobiles for contingency resources during substation construction
    • Microgrids for critical facilities: allows critical facilities to operate independently of the electrical grid during extended grid outages
    • Peak reduction: help resolve potential overloads, address power quality issues at host sites, reduce bills for public sector customers
    • Energy cost: discharge batteries every day for one to four hours, reduction in amount of energy to purchase and charge battery at night at a much lower cost


Appendix

  • Be careful which substation to swap to because we need to pick ones with only two transformers
  • In the future, we would like to look at forecasted loads instead of what would have happened in the past

Energy Storage Capital Expense Optimization

Objective

Each substation in a T&D system has multiple transformers feeding distribution circuits. Each of these substations has a set capacity. Utilities must report capacity overages to regulators. Generally, the sum of all substation transformer ratings defines a substation's capacity. In this case, the utility could monitor the sum of MVA load for all transformers to total MVA normal and 24-hour emergency ratings.  

In order to avoid capacity overages, T&D operators install batteries. Batteries are expensive, so T&D operators must decide carefully what locations make the most sense.  Considerations include:

  • Capability of existing transformers to serve present peak loads
  • Capability of existing transformers to pick up full load of station when other transformer fails
  • Asset health
  • Outage impact
  • Forecasted demand
  • Cost and pricing of battery installation

In general, it makes the most sense to install batteries at substations with high risk of capacity overages. We take this monitoring use case one step further by running what-if scenarios, investigating what would have happened in substations in the past if a transformer had failed.

Link to Organizer Topic

Assemble Data

Process Data

  • Load data is stored in PI - step

Equipment data 

  • Capacity ratings are stored in an SQL database - step

Apply analytics

Build what-if load signals 

  • In this example, we will investigate what would have happened if one transformer had failed during the winter in substation 180
  • First, create capsules for winter with Periodic Condition - step
  • Create load signals for an N-1 scenario that one transformer is lost and the remaining transformer takes on all the load using Formula tool and splice function - step

Identify excursion conditions

  • Use Deviation Search to find when the Winter Scenario load exceeds the 24-hr Emergency Rating - step

Cleanse the load signal to refine excursion characteristics

  • Use Low Pass Filter to cleanse the load signal - step
  • Create another Deviation Search for true excursion detection - step

Quantify count, max duration and energy

  • Use Signal from Condition to totalize differential MVA into MWh - step 
  • Use Scorecard to characterize annual Winter what-if excursion characteristics - step

Scale Across Assets

  • Perform the same what-if analysis on Station 191 using asset swap
    • Trend
    • Scorecard

Results

  • Reduces CapEx by prioritizing battery installation based on actual equipment condition and risk of overload
  • Improves system reliability to avoid $10's of millions in unplanned downtime and CapEx and premature replacement
  • Seeq application allows for
    • Aggregation of data from multiple datasources
    • Investigation of "what-if" scenarios
    • Rapid iteration across assets
  • Installing batteries at a substation improved grid reliability and the ability to meet demand anytime.  Specific benefits include:
    • Solar smoothing: smooth short-term changes in voltage due to intermittent generation
    • Distribution deferral: non-wires alternatives to defer or eliminate the need for traditional utility upgrade
    • Outage management: reduces the cost of deploying mobiles for contingency resources during substation construction
    • Microgrids for critical facilities: allows critical facilities to operate independently of the electrical grid during extended grid outages
    • Peak reduction: help resolve potential overloads, address power quality issues at host sites, reduce bills for public sector customers
    • Energy cost: discharge batteries every day for one to four hours, reduction in amount of energy to purchase and charge battery at night at a much lower cost


Appendix

  • Be careful which substation to swap to because we need to pick ones with only two transformers
  • In the future, we would like to look at forecasted loads instead of what would have happened in the past

Energy Storage Capital Expense Optimization

Objective

Each substation in a T&D system has multiple transformers feeding distribution circuits. Each of these substations has a set capacity. Utilities must report capacity overages to regulators. Generally, the sum of all substation transformer ratings defines a substation's capacity. In this case, the utility could monitor the sum of MVA load for all transformers to total MVA normal and 24-hour emergency ratings.  

In order to avoid capacity overages, T&D operators install batteries. Batteries are expensive, so T&D operators must decide carefully what locations make the most sense.  Considerations include:

  • Capability of existing transformers to serve present peak loads
  • Capability of existing transformers to pick up full load of station when other transformer fails
  • Asset health
  • Outage impact
  • Forecasted demand
  • Cost and pricing of battery installation

In general, it makes the most sense to install batteries at substations with high risk of capacity overages. We take this monitoring use case one step further by running what-if scenarios, investigating what would have happened in substations in the past if a transformer had failed.

Link to Organizer Topic

Assemble Data

Process Data

  • Load data is stored in PI - step

Equipment data 

  • Capacity ratings are stored in an SQL database - step

Apply analytics

Build what-if load signals 

  • In this example, we will investigate what would have happened if one transformer had failed during the winter in substation 180
  • First, create capsules for winter with Periodic Condition - step
  • Create load signals for an N-1 scenario that one transformer is lost and the remaining transformer takes on all the load using Formula tool and splice function - step

Identify excursion conditions

  • Use Deviation Search to find when the Winter Scenario load exceeds the 24-hr Emergency Rating - step

Cleanse the load signal to refine excursion characteristics

  • Use Low Pass Filter to cleanse the load signal - step
  • Create another Deviation Search for true excursion detection - step

Quantify count, max duration and energy

  • Use Signal from Condition to totalize differential MVA into MWh - step 
  • Use Scorecard to characterize annual Winter what-if excursion characteristics - step

Scale Across Assets

  • Perform the same what-if analysis on Station 191 using asset swap
    • Trend
    • Scorecard

Results

  • Reduces CapEx by prioritizing battery installation based on actual equipment condition and risk of overload
  • Improves system reliability to avoid $10's of millions in unplanned downtime and CapEx and premature replacement
  • Seeq application allows for
    • Aggregation of data from multiple datasources
    • Investigation of "what-if" scenarios
    • Rapid iteration across assets
  • Installing batteries at a substation improved grid reliability and the ability to meet demand anytime.  Specific benefits include:
    • Solar smoothing: smooth short-term changes in voltage due to intermittent generation
    • Distribution deferral: non-wires alternatives to defer or eliminate the need for traditional utility upgrade
    • Outage management: reduces the cost of deploying mobiles for contingency resources during substation construction
    • Microgrids for critical facilities: allows critical facilities to operate independently of the electrical grid during extended grid outages
    • Peak reduction: help resolve potential overloads, address power quality issues at host sites, reduce bills for public sector customers
    • Energy cost: discharge batteries every day for one to four hours, reduction in amount of energy to purchase and charge battery at night at a much lower cost


Appendix

  • Be careful which substation to swap to because we need to pick ones with only two transformers
  • In the future, we would like to look at forecasted loads instead of what would have happened in the past
